div1.p: Latimer writes to Waterson regarding Kissinger's pension.

div1.head: Letter from Caroline Latimer to [s.n.] Waterson, September 26, 1912
div1.p:
I have your note
concerning Kissinger's
pension. The only
announcement that
I ever saw about it
was a statement in
one of the Boston pa-
pers, I think the
Transcrept, which one
of my friends there cut
out and sent me.
AC
In to L
I think I have this
still, but it is put
again away with all
my other papers etc.
in storage and I
could not possibly get
at it.

I know, however,
that the pension is
twelve hundred dol-
lars a year ($1200.)
and it was granted
in the early part of
the year 1911, I
think, though it
might perhaps be safer to
say in the writer of 1910-
1911. I was told by a
friend who takes the Army
and Navy Journal that
there was great difficulty
in getting it, as certain
people said Kissinger
did no more than any
one else. Might have done!

This is all that I know
regarding it and I do not
think the slip I spoke of
contains anything further beyond
facts already known. But
if you want to be sure
there is nothing more to be
said. you might write to
Ms Kissinger. Her address
is 810 Milton Ave
South Bend, Indiana.
